questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department, as he was severely dehydrated. Dehydration is most commonly seen in children. Which of the following statement justify it?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ratio of ECF volume to ICF volume is larger in infants and children than in adults. However, as the total volume of ECF is much smaller in children than in adults. In addition, the regulatory mechanisms for maintaining ECF volume are not well developed in infants and children. Therefore, dehydration is more common and occurs rapidly in children than in adults.

Option A: Incorrect because the ratio of ECF to ICF volume is actually larger in children, not adults.

Option B: Incorrect because the ratio of ICF volume to ECF volume is smaller in children than in adults.

Option D: Incorrect because the ratio of ECF volume to ICF volume is larger in children, not smaller.

Key takeaways:

The ratio of ECF volume to ICF volume is larger in children than in adults, making dehydration more common in children due to smaller total ECF volume and underdeveloped regulatory mechanisms.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male who was a chronic alcoholic was admitted to the medicine ward with generalized edema. Edema is the accumulation of free fluid in the interstitial tissue space. How to determine the interstitial fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Option B: Calculation of Interstitial Fluid Volume. Interstitial fluid volume cannot be measured directly, but it can be calculated as follows:

Interstitial fluid volume = Extracellular fluid volume - Plasma volume

Extracellular fluid volume can be estimated by using radioactive sodium, radioactive chloride, radioactive iothalamate, thiosulfate ion, and Inulin.

Plasma volume can be estimated by using serum albumin labeled with radioactive iodine (125I-albumin) or with a dye that avidly binds to the plasma proteins, such as Evans blue dye (also called T-1824).

Option A: Radioactive sodium and Tritium trioxide - Tritium (³H) is used to measure total body water, not plasma volume, so it cannot be used to calculate interstitial fluid volume.

Option C: Deuterium trioxide and Radiolabelled albumin - Deuterium oxide (D2O) measures total body water, not extracellular fluid volume.

Option D: Radiolabelled water and Radioactive iodine - Radiolabelled water measures total body water, while radioactive iodine is used to label plasma proteins but doesn't measure extracellular fluid.

Key takeaways:

Interstitial fluid volume is calculated as the difference between extracellular fluid volume (measured with radioactive sodium) and plasma volume (measured with radio labelled albumin).

questions.text: In which of the following cases, will the following alterations in the Darrow Yannet diagram be seen?
questions.solution:
Option C: If a hypotonic solution is added to the extracellular fluid, the osmolarity of the extracellular fluid decreases, and some of the extracellular water diffuses into the cells until the intracellular and extracellular compartments have the same osmolarity. Both the intracellular and extracellular volumes are increased by the addition of hypotonic fluid, although the intracellular volume increases largely.

The other options involve different fluid shifts:

Option A: Diarrhoea - Leads to isotonic fluid loss from extracellular fluid.

Option B: Addition of Hypertonic solution - Causes an increase in extracellular osmolarity, drawing water out of cells.

Option D: Hypertension - Doesn't directly affect fluid osmolarity in this way.

Key takeaways:

In SIADH, there is excess water retention leading to the addition of hypotonic fluid to the extracellular space. This decreases osmolarity, and water shifts into cells, increasing both extracellular and intracellular fluid volumes, as shown in the Darrow Yannet diagram.

Reference:

Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page Number-312.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male came for a regular check-up. His weight came out to be 60 kg. What will be the plasma volume and interstitial volume respectively in this male?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

Option B, C, and D does not fit hence incorrect.

Key takeaways:

For a 60 kg male:

  • Plasma volume is typically about 5% of body weight, which is around 3L.
  • Interstitial volume is about 15% of body weight, which is approximately 9L.

questions.text: In the given figure, we can observe a Darrow Yannet diagram. In which of the following condition these alterations will not be seen?
questions.solution:
If a hypertonic solution is added to the extracellular fluid, the extracellular osmolarity increases and causes osmosis of water out of the cells and into the extracellular compartment. Again, almost all the added sodium chloride remains in the extracellular compartment, and fluid diffuses from the cells into the extracellular space to achieve osmotic equilibrium. The net effect is an increase in extracellular volume (greater than the volume of fluid added), a decrease in intracellular volume, and a rise in osmolarity in both compartments.

Option B: In SIADH, hypotonic fluid is added, decreasing osmolarity and increasing both intracellular and extracellular volumes, which differs from the hypertonic shift seen in the other conditions (Hypertension, Addition of hypertonic solution, and Excess intake of NaCl).

Option A: Hypertension - Often associated with sodium retention, which can lead to an increase in extracellular volume and osmolarity.

Option C: Addition of hypertonic solution - Directly increases extracellular osmolarity, causing water to move out of cells.

Option D: Excess intake of NaCl - Increases extracellular sodium concentration, raising osmolarity and drawing water out of cells.

Key takeaways:

In SIADH, hypotonic fluid is added, decreasing osmolarity and increasing both intracellular and extracellular volumes, which differs from the hypertonic shift seen in the other conditions (Hypertension, Addition of hypertonic solution, and Excess intake of NaCl).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man was suffering from bipolar disorder for which he was treated with Lithium. After few days, he was diagnosed with lithium induced diabetes insipidus for which amiloride diuretic is given. Amiloride inhibits which of the following channels?
questions.solution:
Option C: Amiloride: A potassium-sparing diuretic that inhibits epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs) in the kidney.

  • ENaCs Structure:
    • Composed of α, β, and γ subunits.
    • The α subunit is responsible for sodium transport, while the β and γ subunits enhance this process.
  • Role of ENaCs: Regulate extracellular fluid (ECF) volume under the influence of aldosterone.
  • Mechanism of Amiloride: Binds to the α subunit of ENaCs, blocking sodium reabsorption

Why Not Others:

Option A: Na+/K+ ATPase pump: Involved in active transport, but not targeted by amiloride.

Option B: Calcium channel: Amiloride does not act on calcium channels.

Option D: Na+/K+/2Cl- channel: Found in the loop of Henle; amiloride acts on ENaCs, not this channel.

Key takeaways:

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks sodium reabsorption by inhibiting ENaCs in the kidney.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. He has been prescribed Canagliflozin. Which of the following membrane transport will be affected due to Canagliflozin?
questions.solution:
Option B: Canagliflozin: An SGLT-2 inhibitor (sodium-glucose transport protein 2), which blocks glucose reabsorption in the kidneys.

  • Mechanism: SGLT-2 facilitates glucose reabsorption via secondary active transport in the renal tubules.
  • Effect: Inhibition leads to renal glucose loss and improved blood glucose control in diabetes.

Why Not Others:

Option A: Primary active transport: Direct use of ATP, unrelated to SGLT-2 function.

Option C: Endocytosis: Involves vesicle formation, not relevant to Canagliflozin's mechanism.

Option D: Transcytosis: Involves movement of molecules across cells, not affected by SGLT-2 inhibitors.

Key takeaways:

Canagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor that blocks glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion and improved diabetes control.

questions.text: In a 38-year-old smoker there is enlargement of airspace distal to the terminal bronchioles, barrel shaped chest and flattened diaphragm and no cyanosis. There will be decrease in which following membrane transport?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis: Emphysema, characterized by destruction of alveolar walls and loss of surface area for gas exchange.

Gases along the respiratory membrane are transported by diffusion.

Option B: Decreased Diffusion of gases due to:

  • Reduced surface area
  • Increased membrane thickness

Diffusion depends on:

  • Area, concentration gradient, lipid solubility (directly proportional)
  • Membrane thickness, particle size (inversely proportional)

Why Not Others:

Option A: Secondary Active Transport:

Not primarily affected in emphysema; this transport mechanism is more related to solute movement rather than gas diffusion.

Option C: Endocytosis:

This process involves the intake of substances into the cell and is not directly related to gas exchange.

Option D: Exocytosis:

This involves the release of substances from the cell and is not impacted by the conditions present in emphysema.

Key takeaways:

Secondary active transport, endocytosis, and exocytosis are not primarily affected in emphysema as they relate to solute transport or cell substance exchange, rather than gas exchange.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with dysphasia, dysarthria, descending symmetric flaccid paralysis of voluntary muscles, diplopia, decreased deep tendon reflexes, constipation. The probable diagnosis of botulism is made. Which membrane transport is affected?
questions.solution:
Option C: Diagnosis: Botulism, caused by botulinum toxin.

  • Affected Process: Exocytosis, necessary for neurotransmitter release.
  • Mechanism:
    • SNARE proteins (e.g., Synaptobrevin) are crucial for exocytosis of acetylcholine.
    • Botulinum toxin degrades SNARE proteins, inhibiting neurotransmitter release and leading to paralysis.

Why not others:

Option A: Facilitated diffusion is not primarily involved in neurotransmitter release.

Option B: Primary active transport is related to ion movement, not exocytosis.

Option D: Simple diffusion does not apply to neurotransmitter release mechanisms.

Key takeaways:

Botulism inhibits exocytosis by degrading SNARE proteins, leading to paralysis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man was diagnosed with acute congestive heart failure for which he is given loop diuretic and dobutamine. Which of the following membrane transport is most likely to be affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Diagnosis: Acute congestive heart failure.

  • Treatment: Loop diuretic (Furosemide).
  • Affected Process: Secondary active transport.
  • Mechanism:
    • Furosemide inhibits the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter in the loop of Henle, leading to decreased sodium reabsorption and increased diuresis.
    • Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter is secondary active transport.

Why not others:

Option A: Facilitated diffusion is not directly affected by loop diuretics.

Option B: Primary active transport (e.g., Na+/K+ ATPase) continues to function.

Option C: Endocytosis is unrelated to the action of loop diuretics.

Key takeaways:

Furosemide inhibits secondary active transport, affecting sodium reabsorption in heart failure treatment.

questions.text: What is the ratio of Na+K+ ATPase pump regarding above picture?
questions.solution:
• The Na+/K+ ATPase pump normally maintains a ratio of 3:2 for sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) ions.
  • This means for every 3 sodium ions transported out of the cell, 2 potassium ions are transported into the cell, resulting in:
    • Ratio calculation: 3:2 = 1.523 = 1.5

Why not other options:

  • 0.5:
    • Incorrect. This ratio does not represent the actual functioning of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump.
  • 3.5:
    • Incorrect. This value does not correspond to the typical ion exchange ratio of the pump.
  • 2.5:
    • Incorrect. This ratio is not representative of the Na+/K+ ATPase activity.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Na+/K+ ATPase pump operates with a ratio of 3:2, which is essential for maintaining membrane potential and cellular homeostasis.
  • This pump is critical for regulating intracellular and extracellular ion concentrations, affecting overall cell function.

questions.text: What if membrane permeability is zero for potassium and chloride ions then, membrane potential becomes entirely dominated by the concentration gradient of which ions alone?
questions.solution:
• When membrane permeability is zero for potassium (K+) and chloride (Cl-) ions, the membrane potential is solely influenced by the concentration gradient of sodium (Na+).
  • This is because the Nernst equation shows that the potential across the membrane is determined by the concentration gradients of ions to which the membrane is permeable.
  • In this scenario, the membrane potential will reflect the Nernst potential for sodium, as it is the only ion with a concentration gradient influencing the potential.

Incorrect options:

Option A- Chloride:

  • Incorrect. If permeability is zero for chloride, it cannot contribute to the membrane potential.

Option B- Potassium:

  • Incorrect. If there is zero permeability to potassium, it cannot influence the membrane potential.

Option D- None of the above:

  • Incorrect. Sodium is indeed the ion that dominates the membrane potential in this case.

Key Takeaways:

  • If the membrane is impermeable to potassium and chloride, the membrane potential is dominated by sodium ions.
  • Understanding the ion permeability is crucial in determining the resting membrane potential and cellular excitability.

Reference:

Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page Number-64.

questions.text: A model cell with three different transporters (X, Y, and Z) and a resting membrane potential of -90 millivolts is shown. Consider the intracellular and extracellular concentrations of all three ions to be typical of a normal cell. Inhibition of transporter Y with ouabain is most likely to cause which of the following changes in the intracellular concentrations of sodium and calcium ions.
questions.solution:
• Inhibition of transporter Y (which likely functions to move sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) ions against their gradients) leads to:
    • Increased intracellular sodium: Inhibition results in decreased active transport of sodium out of the cell, causing sodium levels to rise within the cell.
    • Increased intracellular calcium: With elevated intracellular sodium, the sodium gradient is reduced. This affects the sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX) mechanism, which relies on the sodium gradient to extrude calcium (Ca2+) from the cell. A lower sodium gradient leads to reduced extrusion of calcium, resulting in increased intracellular calcium

Why not other options:

  • Decreased sodium; decreased calcium:
    • Incorrect. Sodium levels cannot decrease when transporter Y is inhibited; they increase instead.
  • Decreased sodium; increased calcium:
    • Incorrect. Similar to option A, sodium does not decrease with inhibition.
  • Increased sodium; decreased calcium:
    • Incorrect. While sodium increases, calcium cannot decrease due to the impaired extrusion mechanism.

Key Takeaways:

  • Inhibition of the sodium-potassium pump (e.g., transporter Y by ouabain) leads to increased intracellular sodium and calcium concentrations.
  • Understanding the impact of transporters on ion concentrations is crucial in cellular physiology and pathophysiology.

questions.text: A male patient of age 11 presented with recurrent episodes of high blood pressure, dehydration, polyuria, polydipsia, and muscle and bone pain with Rickets. The patient is below average height as per his age. The blood tests show hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia and metabolic acidosis. The urine tests show high glucose, amino acids and phosphate levels in urine. The patient has family history of similar condition. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fanconi Syndrome

  • Symptoms: Polyuria, polydipsia, rickets, muscle/bone pain, growth delay.
  • Labs: Hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, metabolic acidosis; glucose, amino acids, and phosphate in urine.
  • Cause: X-linked recessive affecting the proximal tubules.

Other options:

Option A: Bartter Syndrome: Characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis, and typically presents with low blood pressure rather than recurrent high blood pressure.

Option C: Nephrotic Syndrome: Primarily presents with proteinuria, edema, and hyperlipidemia, not the hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis seen here.

Option D: Liddle Syndrome: Causes hypertension and hypokalemia due to increased sodium reabsorption but does not typically present with polyuria, rickets, or the specific metabolic derangements noted in this patient.

Key takeaways:

Fanconi Syndrome involves proximal tubular dysfunction, leading to characteristic electrolyte imbalances and metabolic acidosis. Other options like Bartter and Liddle syndromes don't match the clinical profile as closely.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to her family physician complaining of fatigue. On investigation Hematocrit: 30%, red blood cell smear: Microcytic hypochromic cells, serum iron values: 27 μg/dL, transferrin saturation: 13%, Serum ferritin: 20 μg/L. Probable diagnosis is iron deficiency anemia is prescribed oral iron supplements. Which of the following food should she avoid taking along with these supplements?
questions.solution:
Option B: Oxalate inhibits the iron absorption by binding and forming insoluble complexes which prevents its GI absorption.

Factors affecting iron absorption:

Why Not Others:

Option A: Citric Acid: Enhances iron absorption and is beneficial when taking iron supplements.

Option C: Ascorbic Acid: Also enhances iron absorption, making it a good choice to take with supplements.

Option D: Amino Acid: Generally enhances iron absorption and does not inhibit it.

Key takeaways:

In iron deficiency anemia, the patient should avoid foods containing oxalates while taking oral iron supplements, as they inhibit iron absorption.

choices.text: Megaloblastic anemia due to Vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text: A 40 years old vegetarian male presented to medicine department with complaints of diarrhea, easy fatigue and decreased appetite. On examination, he was having pallor. There was a loss of sensation in the distal parts of four extremities. Investigations, revealed hemoglobin was 11 gm/d, MCV 110 FL, MCH 45 pg, the peripheral smear was showing large RBC, and hypersegmented neutrophils. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: The probable diagnosis is megaloblastic anemia due to Vitamin B12 deficiency.

  • Symptoms: Diarrhea, fatigue, decreased appetite, pallor, and loss of sensation in extremities suggest neurological involvement.
  • Lab Findings:
    • High MCV (110 fL) and MCH (45 pg) indicate macrocytic anemia.
    • Peripheral smear shows large RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils.
  • Vitamin B12 Deficiency: Causes impaired DNA synthesis, leading to abnormal RBC formation (megaloblasts) and neurological symptoms due to nerve damage.
  • Additional Findings: You might also see Cabot rings, Howell-Jolly bodies, and fine basophilic stippling in the peripheral smear.

Why not others:

Option A: Iron Deficiency Anemia: Would show microcytic anemia (low MCV) and low MCH, not macrocytic changes.

Option C: Anemia of Chronic Disease: Typically presents with normocytic or microcytic anemia and normal or decreased MCV, not macrocytic features.

Option D: Sideroblastic Anemia: Characterized by microcytic anemia and ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow, not macrocytic red blood cells.

Key takeaways:

The presentation of diarrhea, fatigue, decreased appetite, pallor, loss of distal sensation, and laboratory findings (macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils) indicate megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: Your 60-year-old female patient has psoriasis and has been treated with methotrexate for several years. She has no other medical problems and her preventive screenings, including fecal occult blood tests and colonoscopy, have all been normal. She has developed an anemia. Which of the following would you expect to find when working up her anemia?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mechanism of Methotrexate: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to a functional folate deficiency.

Resulting Anemia: Folate deficiency causes macrocytic anemia due to impaired DNA synthesis.

  • Cell Growth: Red cell precursors increase in size but cannot divide, resulting in larger-than-normal cells being released into circulation. Folate along vit B12 is important for RBC maturity. Immature and larger RBCs are released in blood.

Outcome: Decreased overall red cell numbers but increased cell mass leads to anemia.

Why not other options:

  • Option B: Microcytic anemia: Typically caused by iron deficiency or thalassemia, which are not expected with methotrexate use and its mechanism.
  • Option C: Thalassemia: This is a genetic disorder and would not be expected as a result of long-term methotrexate treatment.
  • Option D: Low Vitamin B12 Level: While methotrexate can affect folate metabolism, it primarily leads to folate deficiency rather than a direct deficiency of vitamin B12.

Key takeaways:

In a 60-year-old female patient treated with methotrexate who has developed anemia, you would expect to find macrocytic anemia due to functional folate deficiency from methotrexate's inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase.

questions.text: A female patient of age 25 presented with complaints of fatigue, weight loss, abdomen and joint pain. On examination, Patient found with Arrhythmia, excessive pigmentation of skin along with diabetes, cirrhosis of liver and atrophy of gonads. What is your probable diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Iron Excess (Hemochromatosis)

Key Features:

  • Symptoms:
    • Fatigue, weight loss
    • Abdominal and joint pain
    • Arrhythmia and excessive skin pigmentation
    • Diabetes, cirrhosis of liver, and gonadal atrophy

Mechanism:

  • Iron Overload: Occurs when iron absorption exceeds excretion due to:
    • Excessive iron intake
    • Mutations in HFE gene located on chromosome 6 leads to hereditary hemochromatosis.
    • Increased erythrocyte destruction

Consequences:

  • Hemosiderin Accumulation: Leads to tissue damage, resulting in:
    • Skin pigmentation
    • Pancreatic damage causing diabetes
    • Liver cirrhosis
    • Atrophy of glands

Why not other options:

Option B: Iron Deficiency: Presents with fatigue and pallor but not excessive pigmentation, diabetes, or cirrhosis, which are indicative of iron overload.

Option C: Vitamin B12 Deficiency: Typically causes anemia, neurological symptoms, and fatigue, but not the specific signs of diabetes and cirrhosis seen here.

Option D: Potassium Deficiency: Mainly leads to muscle weakness, cramps, and arrhythmias but does not explain the other systemic issues like pigmentation, liver cirrhosis, and diabetes.

Key takeaways:

Patient with fatigue, weight loss, and skin pigmentation likely has iron overload (hemochromatosis), indicated by diabetes, liver cirrhosis, and gonadal atrophy.

questions.text: Parenteral nutrition is instituted for a 4-day-old infant who has a total bilirubin of 18 mg/dL and a direct bilirubin of 3.0 mg/dL. Which one of the following macronutrients in the parenteral nutrition should be restricted in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Reason for Restriction: Infusion of lipids displaces bilirubin from albumin, increasing the risk of kernicterus.

Infusion Guidelines: Lipids should be administered at a low rate to prevent essential fatty acid deficiency while minimizing bilirubin displacement.

Why not other options:

Option A: Carbohydrate: Carbohydrates do not significantly impact bilirubin levels and are necessary for energy, so they should not be restricted.

Option C: Protein: Proteins are essential for growth and development, and while they can affect bilirubin indirectly, they are not typically restricted in this context.

Option D: Vitamin: Vitamins are necessary for various metabolic processes and are not directly related to bilirubin metabolism, so they do not need to be restricted.

Key takeaways:

In infant with elevated bilirubin levels, fat should be restricted in parenteral nutrition, as it displaces bilirubin from albumin, increasing the risk of kernicterus.

choices.text: Deficiency of the intestinal fructose transporter

questions.text: Abnormally low lactase activity was found in biopsied material from the small intestine of a 2-month old, ill baby who had persistent severe vomiting and diarrhoea. The baby had been breastfed. The low lactase activity could be due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: Impact of Protein Malnutrition: Impairs the synthesis of disaccharides, including lactase.

  • Lactose Hydrolysis: Normally, lactose is broken down into glucose and galactose by lactase in the small intestine.
  • Consequences of Low Lactase Activity: Can lead to clinical symptoms like vomiting, diarrhoea, flatulence and perineal excoriation. Reducing dietary lactose is often necessary, which may also decrease intake of calcium, protein, and vitamins.

Lactose intolerance is different from milk allergy which is an immune response to milk proteins.

Why not other options:

Option A: Congenital Isomaltase Deficiency: This specifically affects isomaltase, not lactase, and would not directly cause low lactase activity.

Option B: Deficiency of the Intestinal Fructose Transporter: This affects fructose absorption, not lactose, so it would not explain low lactase activity.

Option C: Insufficient Secretion of Amylase: Amylase primarily digests starch, not lactose, and would not directly impact lactase levels or activity

Key takeaways:

The abnormally low lactase activity in a 2-month-old ill baby could be due to protein malnutrition, which impairs the synthesis of disaccharidases like lactase in the small intestine. Infection and nutritional injury can also reduce small intestine's ability to produce lactase.

choices.text: Arachidonic acid release from the membrane

questions.text: You prescribe ibuprofen to help reduce your patient's inflammation. Which of the following pathways is blocked as an anti-inflammatory mechanism of action of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mechanism of NSAIDs: NSAIDs like ibuprofen, primarily inhibit the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, blocking the synthesis of prostaglandins which are key mediators of inflammation.

  • Eicosanoid Pathways: Prostaglandins (and thromboxanes) are derived from arachidonic acid through the COX pathway, while leukotrienes are produced via the lipoxygenase pathway.
  • Impact on Inflammation: By blocking prostaglandin synthesis, NSAIDs effectively reduce inflammation and alleviate associated symptoms.

Why not other options:

Option B: Thromboxane Synthesis: While NSAIDs also reduce thromboxane synthesis, the primary anti-inflammatory effect is through the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis.

Option C: Leukotriene Synthesis: Leukotrienes are synthesized via the lipoxygenase pathway, which is not directly affected by NSAID. Therefore, they are not the primary target of ibuprofen.

Option D: Arachidonic Acid Release from the Membrane: This step involves phospholipase A2 and is not directly inhibited by NSAIDs, which primarily act on the cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway to block prostaglandin synthesis.

Key takeaways:

Ibuprofen reduces inflammation by blocking prostaglandin synthesis, which is a key anti-inflammatory mechanism of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
